conversation.text: Hi! Are you ready to start making Spaghetti With Meatballs?
Yes! Let's get started.
Start by whipping the eggs in a small bowl with a teaspoon of salt and your choice of seasonings.
evidence: Whip the eggs in a small bowl with a teaspoon of salt and your choice of seasonings.

conversation.text: What kinds of seasonings can I use?
You can use 1t of Italian seasoning, 1/2 t oregano garlic and onion powder, cracked red pepper, rosemary and thyme
evidence: 1 tablespoon (15ml) of your favorite bottle of "Italian" seasoning.
1/2 teaspoon (7ml) oregano, garlic and onion powder, cracked red pepper, rosemary, and/or thyme

conversation.text: I see. What should I do next?
Place your ground meat in a big bowl
evidence: Choose your ground meat and dump it into a big bowl.

conversation.text: What meat should I use, pork or beef?
You can use either, or both if you'd like
evidence: beef, lamb, and veal

conversation.text: Sounds great. Just put the meat into the bowl. What's next?
Add in the egg, parmesan and bread crumbs. You'll want to mix them well until you have a wet pile of meat when done.
evidence: Pour the egg, Parmesan, and bread crumbs in and mix thoroughly with your hands.

conversation.text: Ok, I just did what you said and the mixture seems sticky now.
That sounds like you're doing it right! Just be sure to not over-mix it or it could make the meat tough.
evidence: Extra mixing isn't helpful, and the more you mix the meat, the tougher it gets.

conversation.text: Thanks for reminder! What's next? Can I roll the ball with mixture now?
Yes! Roll the meat into 1" balls. You can make them larger or smaller if you want, but remember, larger ones need a bit of extra time to cook.
evidence: Roll the meat into 1-inch (2.5 cm) balls.

conversation.text: Hmmm how long does it take to cook 1'' balls?
You have a few options depending on how you'd like to cook them. You can cook in a skillet until brown, cook in a slow cooker for about 6 hours, or bake in an oven for about 20-30 mins.
evidence: Fry the meatballs on the stovetop over medium heat until browned on all sides.
slow-cooked meatballs. To make them, add the sauce and meatballs to the cooker and cook on low heat for 6-8 hours.
Alternatively, bake meatballs for 20-30 min at 350F (175C), turning once or twice.

conversation.text: Ok. What should I do next?
Would you like to fry, slow cook, or bake them?
evidence: Fry the meatballs on the stovetop
Alternatively, bake meatballs for 20-30 min
cooker and cook on low heat for 6-8 hours.

conversation.text: Will that make a difference in the taste?

For the best taste, I'd recommend either the slow cooker or baking them. Both will give a rich flavor - the baking will give a crisp texture I you like that. If you want to fry them, you can also fry them in a bit of sauce that will soak up the flavor. It depends on how much time you have, really.
evidence: beautifully rich, slow-cooked meatballs
For the best meatballs, let them cook in a 1/2" (1-2 cm) of red sauce
rich, crisp flavor and texture, and create far less mess than stovetop cooking.

conversation.text: I'll go with fry then. I am a fan of fried food.
Sounds good! Use a bit of oil, medium heat, and rotate the meatballs occasionally.
evidence: Use a little bit of oil and rotate the meatballs every few minutes until browned and cooked.

conversation.text: How much oil should I use? Should I soak the ball thoroughly?
You only need a little bit of oil, no soaking necessary. You don't want them to stick to the pan. You'll cook them until they are brown on all sides.
evidence: little bit of oil

conversation.text: Ok, I think they're ready now - some even turn black, guess I overcooked them...
It's probably better that meat is overcooked instead of undercooked. If you don't like the "burnt" taste of the blackened parts, you can cut that part off and toss it.
Sounds interesting. What's next?
You can let the meatballs cook for a couple more minutes in some red sauce. That'll give them some extra flavor and make sure they remain tender.
evidence: For the best meatballs, let them cook in a 1/2" (1-2 cm) of red sauce after they've browned -- they'll soak up some of the flavor and liquid to stay tender.

conversation.text: Cool! Can't wait to enjoy it now. Thanks!
Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.

recipe.title: How to Make Spaghetti With Meatballs

procedure.summary: Whip the eggs in a small bowl with a teaspoon of salt and your choice of seasonings.
procedure.description:
Use a fork to beat the eggs, as if you were about to scramble them. Then add some salt and get to work seasoning to your heart's content. You can either make up your own seasoning or use one of the following mixes:
1 tablespoon (15ml) of your favorite bottle of "Italian" seasoning. Note -- check if it already has salt in it before adding separately. 1/2 teaspoon (7ml) oregano, garlic and onion powder, cracked red pepper, rosemary, and/or thyme
1 packet powdered onion or mushroom soup mix. 1 Adobo chili mixture or spice packet, with salt.

procedure.summary: Choose your ground meat and dump it into a big bowl.
procedure.description: Classically, meatballs are made from hamburger meat. But mixing things up, like the lovely Italian trio of beef, lamb, and veal, will lead to spectacular meatballs with little extra work.

procedure.summary: Pour the egg, Parmesan, and bread crumbs in and mix thoroughly with your hands.
procedure.description: Plunge your hands in and really squeeze to mix everything up. If you're squeamish, a stiff spatula or wooden spoon will work as well. Just make sure that everything is evenly blended and you have a wet, seasoned pile of meat when done. If desired, add the small diced onion here as well. Onion, when cooked, is a savory-sweet complement to the meat. Once it looks well mixed, you can stop. Extra mixing isn't helpful, and the more you mix the meat, the tougher it gets.

procedure.summary: Roll the meat into 1-inch (2.5 cm) balls.
procedure.description: You can make any size you want, but 1" balls tend to brown nicely on the outside while cooking quickly enough on the inside. Grab a small pinch of meat and roll it between your palms to get nice round meatballs. If you make larger meatballs, you may need to cook them a little longer, lowering the heat to prevent burning. Smaller balls can dry out if cooked too long. They must hit high heat, brown, and then come off quickly before over-cooking..

procedure.summary: Fry the meatballs on the stovetop over medium heat until browned on all sides.
procedure.description: Use a little bit of oil and rotate the meatballs every few minutes until browned and cooked. If the outsides are done, but the insides are still soft, lower the heat and let them cook for an extra 2-3 minutes. For the best meatballs, let them cook in a 1/2" (1-2 cm) of red sauce after they've browned -- they'll soak up some of the flavor and liquid to stay tender. A slow-cooker filled with sauce and meatballs can accomplish the same thing for beautifully rich, slow-cooked meatballs. To make them, add the sauce and meatballs to the cooker and cook on low heat for 6-8 hours.

procedure.summary: Alternatively, bake meatballs for 20-30 min at 350F (175C), turning once or twice.
procedure.description: Roasted meatballs bring out a rich, crisp flavor and texture, and create far less mess than stovetop cooking. Your biggest worry in the oven is drying out -- be sure to check the smaller balls regularly and take them out as soon as they are cooked all the way through. Once they are just about finished, crank the heat to high or put them in the broiler for 1 minute to get a wonderful brown crust on the tops.
